problem: I had been planning to work for 20 hours a week for 12 weeks this summer to earn $\$3000$ to buy a used car. Unfortunately, I got sick for the first two weeks of the summer and didn't work any hours. How many hours a week will I have to work for the rest of the summer if I still want to buy the car?
solution: If the total amount that I earn for the summer is constant, then the number of hours I work each week and the total number of weeks that I work are inversely proportional. Consequently, if I only work $\frac{10}{12}=\frac56$ as many weeks, I need to work $\frac{6}{5}$ as many hours each week. $\frac{6}{5}\cdot20=24$, so I need to work $\boxed{24}$ hours a week.
model_solution:
Step 1:  Calculate the total number of hours that needed to be worked to earn $\$3000$ at the original rate of 20 hours a week for 12 weeks, by multiplying the number of hours worked per week by the number of weeks worked.
Step 2:  Since I didn't work any hours during the first two weeks, I will need to work the same total number of hours over the remaining 10 weeks to earn $\$3000$.

$\frac{12 \text{ weeks}}{10 \text{ weeks}} = \frac{20 \text{ hours per week}}{x \text{ hours per week}} = 12/10$
$\frac{20}{x} = \frac{12}{10}$
$\frac{20}{x} = \frac{12}{10}$
$\frac{20 \cdot 10}{x \cdot 10} = \frac{12 \cdot 10}{10 \cdot 10}$
$\frac{200}{10x} = \frac{120}{100}$
$\frac{200}{10x} = \frac{6}{5}$
$200 = 10x \cdot \frac{6}{5}$
$200 = 12x$
$\frac{200}{12} = x$
$x = \boxed{16.67}$
$\frac{200}{12} = x$
$\frac{200}{12} = x$
steps: Step 1:  Calculate the total number of hours that needed to be worked to earn $\$3000$ at the original rate of 20 hours a week for 12 weeks, by multiplying the number of hours worked per week by the number of weeks worked.

Step 2:  Since I didn't work any hours during the first two weeks, I will need to work the same total number of hours over the remaining 10 weeks to earn $\$3000$.

$\frac{12 \text{ weeks}}{10 \text{ weeks}} = \frac{20 \text{ hours per week}}{x \text{ hours per week}} = 12/10$
$\frac{20}{x} = \frac{12}{10}$

Step 2:  Since I didn't work any hours during the first two weeks, I will need to work the same total number of hours over the remaining 10 weeks to earn $\$3000$.

$\frac{12 \text{ weeks}}{10 \text{ weeks}} = \frac{20 \text{ hours per week}}{x \text{ hours per week}} = 12/10$
$\frac{20}{x} = \frac{12}{10}$
